content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Sulfur trioxide, <math alttext="S O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, is commercially produced on a massive scale for use in manufacturing. It is also produced as a by-product of burning fossil fuels and is an air pollutant involved in the formation of acid rain. A. In the box below, complete one of the valid Lewis electron-dot diagrams for the <math alttext="S O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule. Be sure to include all valence electrons, including lone pairs.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Sulfur trioxide, <math alttext="S O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, is commercially produced on a massive scale for use in manufacturing. It is also produced as a by-product of burning fossil fuels and is an air pollutant involved in the formation of acid rain. A. In the box below, complete one of the valid Lewis electron-dot diagrams for the <math alttext="S O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule. Be sure to include all valence electrons, including lone pairs.

B. Predict the shape of the <math alttext="S O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule based on the diagram you completed above.

Under some conditions, <math alttext="S O 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> decomposes to produce <math alttext="S O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, as represented by the equation below. <math alttext="2 S O 3, gas, is in equilibrium with 2 S O 2, gas, plus O 2, gas; delta H naught equals, 180 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> C. Under what temperature conditions will the reaction be thermodynamically favored: high temperatures, low temperatures, all temperatures, or no temperatures? Justify your answer in terms of the change in enthalpy and the change in entropy during the reaction.

A chemist fills a rigid vessel with <math alttext="S O 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at a certain temperature until the pressure of <math alttext="S O 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container is <math alttext="0.83 atmosphere" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.83</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The <math alttext="S O 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> decomposes as the partial pressures of <math alttext="S O 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container are monitored over time, as shown in the following graph. A change is made to the system at time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> . D. Answer the following based on the graph. i. Draw an <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the time axis to show when the system first reached equilibrium.

ii. Describe the change that was made to the system at time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> .

iii. After the change was made at time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , the partial pressure of <math alttext="S O 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> increased while the partial pressure of <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> decreased. Explain this observation.

E. Use the information above to answer the following. i. Write the expression for the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , for the reaction.
ii. Determine the value of <math alttext="K sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for the reaction.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
